page.title: 03ECOLOGY - SULLINGTON
page.content: The variation in soil type because of the underlying geology is reflected in the vegetation found in the area. To the South are the chalk downs with steep scarp slopes followed by sandstone. A narrow outcrop of gault clay overlying sandstone is to be found to the north. Greensand is prevalent in the north, providing the best type of sand for the building industry. The weather is slightly warmer on the dip slope of the downs because the cool air collects at the foot of the scarp slope, illustrated by it being the last place for morning mists to clear. Footpaths and bridleways are well marked including the part of the Southdown Way used by ramblers.
